column2: Early Childhood Health, Development, and Nutrition Q&A (LMIC Settings)
Healthcare Professional Expert in Early Child Development (0–5 yrs)
WHO/UNICEF IMCI Guidelines, East Africa MoH Child Health Protocols, LMIC CHW Manuals
Bold headers, wrapped text, alternating row shading
Parental education, CHW training, and app/database integration in LMIC settings

column3: Question
column4: LMIC Guidance for Community Health Workers' Assessment
column5: Green (Normal)
column6: Yellow ( Monitor)
column7: Orange (Urgent)
column8: Red (Emergency)
column9: When to Go to Clinic (When the answer is either orange or red)
column10: LMIC Guidance (Parent-Friendly) (When the answer is yellow)
column11: Preventive Reminder (When the answer is either yellow or green)

column3: Does the infant have fever? For how long? Is the infant feeding normally?
column4: Assess fever source and danger signs per IMCI; check temperature accurately. In malaria-risk areas test for malaria; consider serious bacterial infection in <2 months. Give paracetamol if indicated; refer urgently if young infant or danger signs.
column5: No fever
column6: Mild fever (<38°C), feeding well, alert.
column7: Fever 38–39°C, mild cough/diarrhea, feeding less but still drinks.
column8: Fever ≥39°C, not feeding, convulsions, hard breathing, very sleepy.
column9: Refer to a health facility if fever ≥38°C lasts >1 day, baby feeds poorly, or any danger sign appears. (those explained in the orange and red)
column10: Advise caregiver to keep the baby lightly dressed and Advise caregiver to continue breastfeeding often. Give extra fluids only if advised for age. Refer to a health facility if fever continues or your baby becomes weak or very sleepy.
column11: Ensure timely birth/6‑week vaccines; use insecticide-treated bed net in malaria areas.

column3: Is the infant coughing or breathing fast? Any chest indrawing or difficulty feeding?
column4: Count respiratory rate; look for chest indrawing/stridor/wheeze per IMCI. Consider bronchiolitis/pneumonia/pertussis; give oxygen if hypoxic; start antibiotics if pneumonia suspected; refer if severe.
column5: Occassional cough, feeding well, no fast breathing
column6: Mild cough/cold, no fast breathing.
column7: Cough >2 weeks, feeding less, mild chest indrawing when crying.
column8: Fast breathing, chest indrawing at rest, grunting, bluish lips, pauses in breathing.
column9: Refer to a health facility if cough lasts >2 weeks or if breathing becomes fast or difficult.
column10: Keep the baby away from smoke and dust. Breastfeed frequently and keep the nose clear. Go for a check if breathing seems fast or the cough does not improve.
column11: Avoid indoor smoke; ensure vaccines are up to date (e.g., PCV).

column3: Is the infant having diarrhea? How many times per day? Any blood or signs of dehydration?
column4: Classify dehydration; give ORS per plan A/B; give zinc (10 mg/day if <6 months, 20mg/day if > 6 months) if policy allows; evaluate for sepsis in young infants; refer if severe dehydration or red flags.
column5: Normal stool, drinks/feeds well, active
column6: Loose stools <3/day
column7: Watery stool ≥3/day, fewer wet nappies, dry mouth, drinks eagerly.
column8: Blood in stool, sunken eyes, very sleepy, drinks poorly or vomiting everything.
column9: Refer to a health facility if there is blood in stool, signs of dehydration, or feeding is poor.
column10: Advise caregiver to continue breastfeeding and give small frequent sips of oral rehydration solution (ORS) if advised. Offer zinc if provided by a health worker. Go for care if your baby becomes sleepy or passes very watery stool often.
column11: Handwashing with soap; safe water preparation; keep ORS and zinc at home if available.

column3: Does the infant have a rash? When did it start? Is it spreading or associated with fever?
column4: Differentiate benign rashes vs. infection/allergy; check for measles exposure and vaccine status; treat secondary infection; refer if extensive lesions or systemic illness.
column5: No rash, no fever, baby comfortable and playing
column6: Mild heat rash, no fever, baby comfortable
column7: Rash spreading, lasts >3 days, itchy, mild oozing.
column8: Rash with high fever, non-blanchable rash, blisters/pus, swelling of face, or very sick baby.
column9: Refer to a health facility if the rash is painful has pus, has blisters, or the baby has fever and seems unwell.
column10: Keep the skin clean and dry; dress your baby in light cotton. Avoid new lotions if the skin reacts. Refer or advise caregiver to seek care if the rash worsens or baby develops fever.
column11: Follow immunization schedule; avoid harsh soaps; keep nails short to reduce scratching.

column3: Does the infant have redness, discharge, or swelling around the cord or eyes?
column4: Assess for omphalitis/conjunctivitis; give systemic antibiotics for omphalitis; topical/systemic per protocol for neonatal conjunctivitis; evaluate for gonococcal/chlamydial infection; urgent referral if severe.
column5: Cord is clean and dry, no eye discharge
column6: Little, sticky eye discharge first days.
column7: Redness around cord stump or eyes with yellow discharge but baby well.
column8: Foul cord smell with redness spreading, fever, baby not feeding; severe eye swelling.
column9: Refer to a health facility the same day for any cord/eye infection signs.
column10: Clean the cord dry (no powders/ointments unless advised). Wash hands before touching. If eyes are red with discharge, clean with clean water and Refer or advise caregiver to seek care.
column11: Hand hygiene; dry cord care; avoid harmful substances on the cord.

column3: Does the infant smile, coo, and respond to caregiver voices appropriately for age?
column4: Screen hearing/vision; review caregiver–infant interaction; provide early stimulation guidance; refer for developmental/hearing assessment if red flags.
column5: Smiles by ~6–8 weeks; coos by ~3 months; looks at faces.
column6: Limited social smile by 3 months; little vocalization.
column7: No response to faces/sound; no smile by 3 months.
column9: Refer to a health facility if there is no social smile or response to sound by 3 months.
column10: Talk, sing, and smile with your baby every day. Hold your baby close and look into their eyes during feeding and play.
column11: Encourage daily responsive play; track milestones on the child health card.

column3: Does the infant hold the head steady and attempt to roll when on the tummy?
column4: Assess tone and primitive reflexes; screen for CP/neuromuscular issues; coach caregivers on positioning; refer if abnormal neuro signs.
column5: Holds head steady by ~4 months; rolls by ~4–6 months.
column6: Poor head control by 4 months; not attempting to roll by 6 months.
column7: Very floppy or very stiff; persistent head lag past 5–6 months.
column9: Refer to a health facility if head control is poor by 4–5 months or very stiff/floppy.
column10: Give tummy time while the baby is awake and watched. Play on a mat and encourage reaching and turning.
column11: Provide supervised tummy time; avoid prolonged device seating.

column3: Does the infant respond to your voice or startle to loud sounds?
column4: Perform hearing screening if available; inquire about ear infections and family history; refer for audiology/ENT if concern.
column5: Startles to loud sound; turns to voices by ~4–6 months.
column6: Inconsistent response to sound; limited babbling by 6 months.
column7: No reaction to loud sounds; no vocalization.
column9: Refer to a health facility if your baby does not react to loud sounds or voices.
column10: Speak gently to your baby and use songs and simple words. Reduce loud background noise during play and feeding.
column11: Avoid loud noise exposure; treat ear infections promptly.

column3: Does the infant open and close hands, grasp objects, and bring hands to the mouth?
column4: Check tone/asymmetry; screen for hemiparesis; provide early intervention/referral.
column5: Hands open/close, brings hands to mouth, grasps by ~3–4 months.
column6: Persistent fisting after 4 months; uses one hand much more.
column7: Very stiff hands/arms; no reaching by 6 months.
column9: Go for assessment if fists stay tightly closed after 4 months or no reaching by 6 months.
column10: Offer simple toys to hold and bring to the mouth. Play gently with both hands to encourage movement.
column11: Offer safe rattles and soft toys; vary sides when feeding/carrying.

column3: Is the infant alert during wake periods and easily roused for feeds?
column4: Evaluate for jaundice, bulging fontanelles, infection, hypoglycemia, dehydration in young infants; advise safe sleep practices; refer if lethargic.
column5: Newborns sleep 14–17 hours/day in short blocks; wakes to feed.
column7: Very irritable or hard to console
column8: Very difficult to wake, poor feeding, limp.
column9: Refer to a health facility if your baby is very sleepy and not feeding.
column10: Newborns need lots of sleep. Wake for feeds and keep a calm, regular routine.
column11: Promote safe sleep (on back, firm surface, no soft bedding).

column3: Is the infant breastfeeding on demand? How many feeds does the infant receive per day?
column4: Support exclusive breastfeeding to 6 months; assess latch/position; manage mastitis; track growth; refer for lactation support if needed.
column5: On demand, about 8–12 times/day; baby gains weight and has wet nappies.
column7: Feeds <6 times/day; shallow latch; slow weight gain.
column8: Not breastfeeding or refusing formula feeds; weight loss.
column9: Refer to a health facility if the baby feeds poorly or is losing weight.
column10: Breastfeed whenever your baby wants, day and night. Check latch and hold the baby close. Ask for help if nipples are sore or baby seems unsatisfied.
column11: Growth monitoring monthly; encourage skin‑to‑skin; avoid water/other foods.

column3: Does the infant spit up small amounts after feeding or vomit forcefully?
column4: Differentiate GER vs. obstruction/infection; check hydration/weight; consider allergy if eczema/hematochezia; refer if red flags.
column5: Occasional spitups; steady weight gain
column6: Small spit-ups after feeds; steady weight gain
column7: Frequent large spit-ups; back-arching; irritable; stagnating weight gain
column8: Green/bloody vomit, projectile vomiting, bilious vomiting, poor breast/formula-feeding.
column9: Refer or advise caregiver to seek care urgently for green/bloody vomit or if baby seems very unwell.
column10: Keep baby upright after feeding and burp gently. Offer smaller, more frequent feeds if needed.
column11: Avoid overfeeding; ensure safe preparation if expressed milk used.

column3: Is the infant receiving only breast milk or given formula top/ups?
column4: Reinforce exclusive breastfeeding; counsel against teas/juices; assess hydration if diarrhea/fever.
column5: No formula milk needed for top-up while exclusively feeding
column6: Little formula required while exclusively breastfed.
column7: Hot climate with fussiness but still feeding; consider counseling.
column8: Refuses to breast/formula feed; signs of dehydration.
column9: Refer to a health facility if baby shows dehydration or refuses feeds.
column10: Under 6 months, breast milk is enough. Extra water or juices are not needed and can be unsafe.
column11: Promote safe water practices for caregivers; exclusive breastfeeding to 6 months.

column3: Does the infant refuse one breast or feed less on one side? Is there pain or discmfort during breastfeeding?
column4: Assess for latch, pain, oral thrush, ear pain; screen for torticollis; provide lactation support; treat underlying causes.
column5: Breastfeeding comfortably on both breasts
column6: Occasional preference; overall feeding well and gaining; mild nipple pain
column7: Persistent refusal but takes the other side; moderate nipple pain; swelling and abnormal warmth of the breast; flattened nipples
column8: Refusal to breast feed from both nipples, severe nipple pain, obvious breast swelling, tenderness; abnormla nipple discharge
column9: Go for assessment if refusal persists or baby is not gaining weight.
column10: Try different positions and start on the preferred breast, then switch. Feed in a quiet, calm place.
column11: Check for oral thrush; encourage frequent, calm feeds; track weight.

column3: Has the infant gained weight steadily along the growth chart?
column4: Plot weight-for-age; assess feeding technique and maternal well-being; screen for illness; manage undernutrition early; refer if red flags.
column5: Steady weight gain along the growth chart; alert and active.
column6: Weight gain slower than expected; misses feeds.
column7: Weight loss or crossing down growth lines
column8: Swelling/oedema/wasting
column9: Refer to a health facility if weight gain is poor or weight is dropping.
column10: Bring the child health card to each visit to check weight. Feed often and ask for help if feeding is difficult.
column11: Monthly growth monitoring; maternal nutrition and hydration support.

column3: Does the child have fever? For how long? Is the child drinking and playing normally?
column4: Use IMCI to assess fever source; test for malaria in endemic zones; check urine/ear/throat as indicated; manage with antipyretics, fluids; treat malaria or bacterial infection as per guidelines; refer if danger signs.
column5: No fever, active/playful
column6: Short fever with mild cold; active; drinking.
column7: Fever ≥38°C for >24 hours; reduced play; decreased appetite.
column8: Very sleepy, convulsions, stiff neck, severe dehydration, or breathing difficulty.
column9: Refer to a health facility if fever lasts >1 day, >38 , child is very sleepy, or has breathing problems.
column10: Give plenty of fluids and Advise caregiver to continue breastfeeding/feeding. In malaria areas, a test at a health center helps find the cause. Go sooner if your child seems worse.
column11: Use insecticide-treated nets nightly; ensure vaccinations up to date.

column3: Is the child coughing or breathing fast? Any chest indrawing or noisy breathing?
column4: Count respiratory rate per age; assess hypoxia; classify per IMCI; give first dose antibiotic if pneumonia suspected; oxygen if needed; refer if severe.
column5: Occassional cough, no fast breathing; active; feeding well
column6: Mild cough/cold
column7: Cough >2 weeks or fast breathing without distress; mild chest indrawing when upset.
column8: Fast breathing with chest indrawing at rest, grunting, cyanosis, or inability to drink.
column9: Refer to a health facility urgently if breathing is fast or difficult.
column10: Keep your child comfortable and away from smoke. Offer fluids often and Refer or advise caregiver to seek care if breathing looks hard or ribs pull in.
column11: Reduce indoor smoke; PCV/pertussis vaccine adherence.

column3: Does the child have diarrhea? How many times per day? Any blood or dehydration signs?
column4: Assess dehydration; ORS Plan A/B; zinc 20 mg/day (6–59 months); test for malaria if fever; antibiotics for dysentery; refer if severe dehydration.
column5: No loose stools; feeding well
column6: 3–4 loose stools/day
column7: Many watery stools; thirst; dry mouth; fewer wet nappies.
column8: Blood in stool, sunken eyes, lethargy, drinks poorly or vomits everything.
column9: Refer to a health facility if there is blood in stool or signs of dehydration.
column10: Give ORS after each loose stool and continue feeding. Give zinc for 10–14 days if provided by a health worker.
column11: Safe water, handwashing with soap, clean feeding utensils.

column3: Does the child have ear pain or discharge? For how long? Any fever or swelling behind the ear?
column4: Assess for AOM/otorrhea; treat pain/fever; antibiotics per guidelines if AOM; topical therapy for chronic suppurative otitis media; refer if mastoiditis signs.
column5: No ear tugging, no ear discharge, no fever
column6: Brief tugging with a cold
column7: Ear pain with fever or discharge but child playful.
column8: Severe pain, swelling behind ear, high fever, or child very ill.
column9: Go for care within 24 hours for ear pain; urgently if swelling or high fever.
column10: Keep the ear dry and do not insert objects. Refer or advise caregiver to seek care for pain or any discharge.
column11: Avoid bottle propping; keep nose clean; follow-up if discharge persists.

column3: Has the child been dewormed recently? Are there signs of worms or poor appetite/weight loss?
column4: Follow national deworming policy (e.g., albendazole/mebendazole from 12 months; 6‑ or 12‑monthly in high-risk areas). Screen for anemia; treat and counsel on hygiene.
column5: No tummy pain/discomfort
column6: Occasional tummy discomfort; otherwise well.
column7: Poor appetite, mild weight loss, visible worms in stool.
column8: Severe anemia signs (pale palms), swollen belly, vomiting worms.
column9: Go for deworming advice if appetite/weight are poor; urgently if severe symptoms.
column10: Deworming helps children grow and play better. A health worker can tell you when your child should take the medicine.
column11: Handwashing, short nails, safe latrines; promote footwear where hookworm risk exists.

column3: Can the child stand with support or walk alone appropriate for age?
column4: Examine tone/reflexes; check for rickets/iron deficiency; consider CP/neuromuscular issues; early intervention referral as needed.
column5: Stands with support by ~10 months; walks by ~15 months.
column6: Not walking by 18 months; unusual walking pattern.
column7: Not bearing weight by 12 months; very stiff/floppy.
column9: Go for assessment if not walking by 18 months or not standing by 12 months.
column10: Give your child safe space to cruise and practice steps. Hold hands and encourage short walks.
column11: Sunlight exposure and diet with vitamin D/calcium; safe play areas.

column3: Does the child respond to name and use simple words for age?
column4: Screen hearing; assess language and social communication; check for chronic ear disease; refer for speech/hearing evaluation or developmental clinic.
column5: Says a few single words by 12–15 months; follows simple commands by ~18 months.
column6: No single words by 18 months; limited understanding; few gestures.
column7: No response to name/sound; no babble by 12 months; regression of skills.
column9: Refer to a health facility if no words by 18 months or no response to sound.
column10: Talk, sing, and read simple picture books daily. Use short, clear phrases and name everyday objects.
column11: Limit screen time; increase caregiver–child interaction and book sharing.

column3: Does the child play, imitate, and explore toys or people around them?
column4: Coach responsive caregiving; observe joint attention; screen for ASD if concerns; provide community referral pathways.
column5: Imitates actions; explores; brings objects to show.
column6: Limited play variety; prefers repetitive actions only.
column7: No interest in people/toys; no eye contact.
column9: Seek assessment if child avoids interaction or stops doing skills they had.
column10: Play simple games like rolling a ball, stacking cups, and naming objects. Praise small efforts and make play part of daily routines.
column11: Daily playtime; simple homemade toys; encourage other children’s play.

column3: Does the child use both hands equally to grasp, feed, and stack objects?
column4: Assess fine motor skills; check vision; address hemiparesis; provide early therapy advice; refer if significant delay.
column5: Feeds self with fingers; stacks 2–3 blocks by ~18 months.
column6: Messy feeding; drops objects often; limited pincer grasp by 12–15 months.
column7: Avoids using one hand entirely; no purposeful grasp by 12 months.
column9: Go for assessment if hand use is very limited or clearly one-sided.
column10: Offer soft finger foods and let your child practice. Give safe cups and blocks for practice.
column11: Encourage self-feeding; provide cups/spoons suited to small hands.

column3: Does the child have frequent tantrums, sleep problems, or difficulty calming down?
column4: Assess for sleep, nutrition, family stressors; coach positive parenting; rule out iron deficiency or neurodevelopmental disorders; refer if concerning.
column5: Short tantrums; calms with comfort; normal separation protest.
column6: Frequent long tantrums; sleep problems; biting/hitting often.
column7: Hurts self/others seriously; loss of skills; no response to comfort.
column9: Refer or advise caregiver to seek care if behavior is severe, persistent, or skills regress.
column10: Keep routines steady, offer choices, and praise calm behavior. Comfort your child during new situations.
column11: Regular routines; outdoor play; avoid harsh discipline.

column3: Has the child started complementary foods at 6 months? What types and how often?
column4: Counsel on frequency, diversity, and texture; Advise caregiver to continue breastfeeding; manage feeding difficulties; monitor growth closely.
column5: Start at 6 months with soft mashed foods while continuing breastfeeding.
column6: Started before 6 months or delayed after 6 months; limited variety.
column7: Not starting solids by 9 months; choking episodes; weight faltering.
column9: Go for counseling if solids are not started by 9 months or weight drops.
column10: Begin with soft porridge, mashed vegetables, beans, and small amounts of animal-source foods if available. Offer 2–3 meals/day plus snacks.
column11: Add oil/groundnuts/egg to increase energy; use clean utensils.

column3: Is the child eating a variety of foods? Are there feeding difficulties or refusal?
column4: Assess for anemia, oral problems, or illness; provide responsive feeding counseling; consider micronutrient supplementation per policy.
column5: Good appetite daily; steady weight gain/growth
column6: Appetite varies day to day; growth steady.
column7: Prefers few foods; refuses new textures; slow meals.
column8: Persistent refusal with weight loss or illness signs.
column9: Refer or advise caregiver to seek care if poor intake lasts >1 week or weight is dropping.
column10: Offer small portions often and eat together. Keep mealtimes calm and try foods many times in different ways.
column11: Regular growth checks; iron‑rich foods (beans, eggs, meat if available).

column3: How many meals and snacks does the child eat daily? Are portions age-appropriate?
column4: Reinforce age‑appropriate frequency and portion sizes; encourage animal-source foods where possible; monitor growth.
column5: 6–8 months: 2–3 meals + 1–2 snacks; 9–24 months: 3–4 meals + 1–2 snacks.
column7: Too few meals; mostly thin porridge; little protein.
column8: Refuses most foods; visible wasting or edema.
column9: Go for assessment if eating very little with weight loss.
column10: Offer meals at regular times and include varied foods. Advise caregiver to continue breastfeeding on demand.
column11: Keep a simple meal schedule posted at home; include fruits/vegetables daily.

column3: Does the child eat iron-rich foods like beans, greens, eggs, or meat when available?
column4: Screen for anemia; treat per protocol (iron, deworming); counsel on diet and malaria prevention in endemic zones.
column5: Eats diverse diet including beans, dark greens, eggs; active and playful.
column7: Mostly starches; pale palms; gets tired easily.
column8: Very pale, weak, swollen feet, or breathless.
column9: Go for testing if your child is very pale, weak, or not improving with better diet.
column10: Offer beans, peas, lentils, dark green leaves, eggs, and meat/fish if available. Give vitamin C foods (oranges, tomatoes) with meals.
column11: Deworming as per policy; malaria prevention; iron-rich foods routinely.

column3: Does the child drink excessive milk that replaces other foods?
column4: Counsel to limit excess milk to avoid iron deficiency and appetite suppression; assess for lactose intolerance or allergy if symptoms.
column5: 1–2 cups/day along with solid foods; eats varied diet.
column7: Milk replaces meals; constipation; picky eating worsens.
column8: Vomiting after any food/drink with dehydration
column9: Refer or advise caregiver to seek care if child relies mostly on milk or reacts to milk.
column10: Milk can be part of the diet, but meals and snacks are also needed. Offer milk after meals, not before.
column11: Promote balanced meals first; brush teeth twice daily.

column3: Does the child have frequent coughs or colds? Are there breathing difficulties or prolonged coughs?
column4: Assess for chronic cough, asthma, TB exposure; measure RR, SpO₂; treat per IMCI; refer if severe.
column5: No coughs, no breathing difficulties
column6: Several mild colds/year; recovers in a few days; active.
column7: Cough >3 weeks; wheeze with play; night cough.
column8: Breathing difficulty, chest indrawing, high fever, lethargy.
column9: Refer to a health facility if cough lasts >2–3 weeks or breathing is hard.
column10: Most children get colds. Give fluids and rest and keep away from smoke. Refer or advise caregiver to seek care if breathing becomes fast or the cough does not settle.
column11: Avoid smoke; ensure vaccines current; seek TB screening if exposure.

column3: Does the child hear and see clearly during daily activities?
column4: Screen hearing and vision; check ears for wax/chronic infection; red reflex; refer to audiology/ophthalmology if needed.
column5: Sees well and hears well
column6: Turns up sound; squints or sits very near; bumps into objects.
column8: No response to loud sounds; frequent falls; eye crossing/white reflex.
column9: Go for auditory/vision assessment if vision/hearing problems are present
column10: Watch how your child responds to voices and objects. Visit a health center if they struggle to hear or see clearly.
column11: Treat ear infections early; keep screening at school entry.

column3: Has the child been dewormed? Are there signs of worms or anemia?
column4: Follow national deworming schedule; treat anemia; counsel hygiene and footwear; consider schistosomiasis risk by locale.
column5: Recently dewormed
column6: Occasional tummy aches; otherwise well.
column7: Passing many worms
column8: Very pale (dizziness, fainting); swollen belly; severe pain.
column9: Refer to a health facility for deworming guidance; urgently if severe symptoms.
column10: Deworming helps children grow. Teach handwashing and use of latrines. Go for advice if appetite is poor or belly is swollen.
column11: Regular handwashing; nails short; safe toilets; footwear where needed.

column3: Does the child appear unusually tired, pale, or weak during play?
column4: Evaluate for anemia, undernutrition, chronic illness; check diet diversity; deworm; manage per findings; refer if severe.
column5: Active most days; normal sleep and play.
column7: Tires easily; pale palms; frequent infections.
column8: Very weak, breathless, swollen feet, or weight loss.
column9: Refer to a health facility if fatigue is persistent or severe.
column10: Offer regular meals and sleep routines. Refer or advise caregiver to seek care if your child looks pale or becomes weak.
column11: Iron‑rich foods and deworming per policy; growth monitoring.

column3: Does the child have tooth pain, cavities, or difficulty eating?
column4: Provide fluoride toothpaste advice; assess for dental caries; analgesia/antibiotics only if infection; refer to dental services.
column5: No tooth pain, no cavities, brushes teeth, eats well
column6: Small spots, poor brushing of teeth, mild pain
column7: Tooth pain when eating; visible cavities; bad breath.
column8: Facial swelling, fever, spreading infection or inability to eat.
column9: Go to a dental/health center if pain persists or there is swelling/fever.
column10: Brush teeth twice daily and limit sugary drinks and snacks. Visit a clinic if a tooth hurts or a hole is seen.
column11: Rinse after sweets; schedule routine dental checks if available.

column3: Can the child speak in short sentences and be understood by caregivers?
column4: Assess hearing; screen language/articulation; check for chronic ear disease; refer for speech–language therapy as available.
column5: Understood by familiar people; speaks short sentences by 3–4 years.
column6: Often hard to understand at 4 years; limited vocabulary.
column7: Not speaking in sentences; cannot follow simple instructions.
column9: Go for assessment if speech is unclear at 4 years or understanding is poor.
column10: Talk face-to-face and give time to answer. Read picture books and repeat new words in daily routines.
column11: Limit background noise; regular conversation and book sharing.

column3: Does the child play and interact with others appropriately for age?
column4: Screen for ASD; observe joint attention and social reciprocity; coach caregivers on social play; refer to developmental services.
column5: Parallel play at 3 years; begins cooperative play by 4–5 years.
column6: Prefers to be alone; limited pretend play; rigid routines.
column7: No eye contact; no interest in peers; repetitive behaviors with distress.
column9: Seek assessment if social interaction is very limited or causes distress.
column10: Invite simple games with other children and model sharing. Keep routines but allow small changes.
column11: Daily outdoor play with peers; reduce screen time; praise sharing.

column3: Is the child toilet trained during the day? Any frequent accidents?
column4: Assess constipation/UTI; support behavioral toilet training; investigate if neurological signs; refer if persistent.
column5: Daytime trained by ~3 years; night wetting may continue up to 5 years.
column6: Frequent daytime accidents at 4 years; constipation.
column7: Painful urination, blood, persistent incontinence after 5 years.
column9: Go for assessment if accidents are frequent or painful urination occurs.
column10: Take your child to the toilet regularly and praise small successes. Avoid punishment for accidents.
column11: Adequate fiber/water; scheduled toilet times; calm routine.

column3: Does the child have difficulty focusing or sitting quietly during simple tasks?
column4: Assess sleep/nutrition; observe across settings; coach positive behavior strategies; consider neurodevelopmental evaluation if impairment.
column5: Short attention span improves with age; can follow simple rules.
column6: Very distractible at home and preschool; disrupts play.
column7: Unsafe impulsivity; aggression; loss of skills.
column9: Refer or advise caregiver to seek care if behavior affects safety or learning.
column10: Use short, clear instructions and break tasks into small steps. Give active play time outdoors daily.
column11: Consistent routines; positive attention; limit sugary drinks and screen time.

column3: Can the child follow simple instructions, name objects, and engage in learning play?
column4: Promote early literacy/numeracy through play; screen hearing/vision; address developmental delays; refer for support services.
column5: Can name objects, colors; follows 2-step commands; draws simple shapes.
column6: Struggles with simple instructions; limited interest in books.
column7: Loses skills or cannot understand simple language.
column9: Seek assessment if understanding or skills decline.
column10: Read and talk about pictures daily. Let your child draw and sort objects by color and size.
column11: Daily story time; simple counting games; praise efforts.

column3: Does the child eat three meals and healthy snacks daily? Any feeding issues?
column4: Assess diet diversity and illness; screen for anemia; provide responsive feeding counseling; treat underlying issues.
column5: Appetite varies; growth steady; active.
column6: Small portions for many days; limited variety.
column7: Refuses most foods; weight loss or illness signs.
column9: Go for assessment if poor intake lasts >3-4 days or weight drops.
column10: Offer small meals and healthy snacks. Eat together and keep mealtimes calm and regular.
column11: 3 meals + 2 snacks daily; include protein, vegetables, and fruit.

column3: Does the child eat foods from all main groups: staples, protein, vegetables, and fruit?
column4: Counsel on food groups and portions; address affordability with local options; monitor growth.
column5: Eats from all groups: staple, legumes, vegetables, fruit, animal-source if available.
column6: Eats from all groups: staple, legumes, vegetables, fruit, animal-source if available.
column7: Only porridge/tea; visible wasting/edema.
column9: Refer or advise caregiver to seek care if weight is dropping or child seems weak.
column10: Give 3 meals and 2 snacks with different foods and colors. Add beans, eggs, or fish/meat if available.
column11: Add a spoon of oil or groundnuts to increase energy; safe food hygiene.

column3: Does the child consume sugary foods or drinks frequently, replacing main meals?
column4: Counsel on caries prevention and nutrition; address appetite suppression by sugary drinks; refer to dental if caries or pain.
column5: Occasional treats; regular brushing; meals not replaced by sweets.
column6: Frequent sweets; refuses meals; dental spots.
column7: Severe tooth decay, pain, or infection; poor eating.
column9: Go to a health/dental center if teeth hurt or eating is affected.
column10: Limit sugary drinks and juices. Offer water and milk and keep sweets as small occasional treats.
column11: Brush teeth twice daily with fluoride toothpaste; routine dental checks if available.

column3: Does the child drink one to two cups of milk daily with meals, not replacing other foods?
column4: Limit excess milk to prevent iron deficiency and poor intake; assess for intolerance/allergy if symptoms; diversify diet.
column5: About 1–2 cups/day with meals; eats varied foods.
column6: Milk before meals reduces appetite; constipation occurs.
column7: Only milk diet; poor growth; vomiting/diarrhea after milk.
column9: Refer or advise caregiver to seek care if child relies mostly on milk or reacts to milk.
column10: Serve milk after meals, not before. Encourage water between meals.
column11: Prioritize balanced meals; iron‑rich foods daily.

column3: Has the child lost weight or failed to gain recently? Any swelling or fatigue?
column4: Assess for acute/chronic malnutrition (MUAC/WHZ); deworm; check anemia/infections; provide nutrition support and follow-up; refer if severe.
column5: Active and playful; eating varied foods; stable growth line.
column6: Slightly underweight; clothes looser; recent illness.
column7: Weight loss
column8: Swelling (edema), or very weak.
column9: Refer to a health facility for assessment if weight is falling or swelling appears.
column10: Offer extra meals and add energy-dense foods like oil, groundnuts, eggs, or beans. Encourage frequent small portions.
column11: Regular growth monitoring and prompt illness treatment.
